bibl.title: Despatch from Beverly Y. Payne to William F. Wharton, July 1, 1891
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p: Consulate General of the United States Monrovia, July 1st 1891
Mr Beverly Y. Payne, To the Department of State.
Explanation of quarterly account rendered, and the effect of the late Consul General A. Clark
Consulate General of the United States Monrovia, July 1, 1891
Hon., William F. Wharton, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington, D. C.

Sir: I have the honor respectfully to state, that I have rendered full Account for the quarter ended June 30th 1891. Sixty days of which the late Consul General Clark was in charge: there are no outstandings in paid quarter but his salary.

I have not assumed to charge any of his personal nor burial expenses to the Government, but will ship his affects to his relative in Muscatine, Iowa and under full account to them, by an American Bark, expected at this port daily, and I have so informed them.
copy of said account on file in the Consulate, and if required, can furnish the Department with same.
I have the honor to be, Sir, Your obedient Servant,
Beverly Y. Payne U.S. Vice Consul
